Alfonso CuarÃ³n: The Conscious Cinema

19/02/2021

Camila Hernandez collects the black-and-white fragments of memory and time in Roma

Image by Netflix

By Sam Harding

How do you capture the authenticity of a memory?

A cast of non-actors. A colourless screen. An opening shot of a floor being washed for five minutes. Moments of waiting.

And waiting.

â€œI think I wanted to understand, to put the pieces together,â€ CuarÃ³n says, speaking toÂ VarietyÂ on a whirlwind day of promoting the film ahead of its New York Film Festival premiere. â€œ[Jorge Luis] Borges talks about how memory is an opaque, shattered mirror, but I see it more as a crack in the wall. The crack is whatever pain happened in the past. We tend to put several coats of paint over it, trying to cover that crack. But itâ€™s still there.â€

Alfonso CuarÃ³n manages to recreate this memory in his film Roma â€“ a wholly apathetic homage to his childhood carer â€“ by respecting the sole integrity of the space, time and emotion needed to form a moment. Guiding us through 1970s Mexico, CuarÃ³n takes time to familiarise us with the people he knew, the places he went to, and the moments he lived in them. He almost utilises landscape and cityscape as a body; unpicking its anatomy through wide-pan, long shots which cunningly and slowly reveal more telling details (i.e. how shopping for a crib can turn strangely violent). However, if youâ€™re the type to curse John Lewis ads for making our winter holidays feel the most â€˜Merry Sad-masâ€™ theyâ€™ve ever felt, youâ€™d only notice these nuances the second time you attempt to watch this film without making everything go wobbly through your tears, or having to pause it to defrost your third pint of ice cream.

Yes, you read that correctly. Third. No judgement here. You go watch it and tell me if youâ€™re okay afterwards.

Roma, like CuarÃ³nâ€™s previous films, is invested in the intimacy and testament of life, the moments we create and share in, and the memories which seduce us back to the nostalgia of the past. For a filmmaker who has long immersed himself in his creations, from the semi-autobiographical road-trip saga Y Tu MamÃ¡ TambiÃ©n, to the whizz-bang majesty of space epic Gravity (earning him an Oscar), Roma would be his own personal homage. Hence, CuarÃ³n ventured out into an exhaustive search throughout Mexican cities and villages, drawing from his own memories to cast the right doppelgangers. In turn, CuarÃ³n decided to pay tribute to the maid who helped raise him and his siblings in Mexico City, shifting the focus away from his limited childhood perspective. It was a story he knew he had to tell. On the one hand, to voice the deeply human story of Mexico, of domestic workers, and of the social strife amidst political turmoil of the 1970s. On the other, to deliver an experience that perhaps no other filmmaker has offered as of yet. In my completely unbiased opinion, might I add.

Each frame is populated with clutter, empty space, overlapping voices unheard, burdensome silences, yet he refuses to give us access to colour. In turn, he shows us ways in which scenes can be made to radiate vibrancy in what the images he presents to us make us feel, tracking movement so seamlessly that we feel as if we are reduced to the man crossing the street who overhears the conversations of women through a shop window on his way to work. Their laughter now becomes all we can hear, and now the two worlds collide, spilling over and intruding with an unprocessed life that, CuarÃ³n seems to suggest, happens constantly without us realising.

Life, events, and people just happen, and we happen around them.

In revisiting the past, CuarÃ³n does not solidify time, nor change its state â€“ he simply lets it flow. Many mainstream films are adored for racing forward, hurling themselves at us in fear that they might lose our interest just for a second. CuarÃ³n, on the other hand, respects the ever-changing nature of time and what it can reveal, smuggling in moments of near-silence, letting a scene breathe. We are forced to surrender to every situation we are presented to, to indulge in it, to hope that the traumatic volumes of mundane life subside with time. But, as in reality, we can never be certain if moments of happiness present themselves to us as beginnings disguised as endings. Like the non-actors cast to partake in Roma, their unprompted reactions mirror our own, as the unpredictability of life is emulated through CuarÃ³nâ€™s translucent, mirror-like lens, taking centre stage without explanation, permission, or resolution.

By sidestepping that heavily underlined (like your dates and titles in primary school) imperative to unremittingly entertain, Roma coaxes us to abandon our consumerism, and simply receive this memory as if it were our own. Instead of making a grand-theatrical impression, CuarÃ³n effectively realises that it is greater than any one definition or manner of exhibition; in his own words, â€œCinema is a mystery that we wonâ€™t solve in a lifetime. Thatâ€™s itâ€™s beauty.â€ When this film ended, I thought more than ever about what Roger Ebert would have to say about it. Perhaps because it so unapologetically encompasses what he himself considered the role of praise-worthy cinema as an â€œempathy machine.â€ We should be thankful for films like Roma, which, undoubtedly, prove that this machine is still humming.

Editor's Note: Roma is available to stream on Netflix
